#Text=Fiat Mistura
#Text=This solution deposits in a few hours the greater part of the strychnine salt as an insoluble bromide in transparent crystals .
#Text=A lady in England lost her life by taking a similar mixture : the precipitated strychnine collected at the bottom , and in taking the last dose she swallowed nearly all of it !
#Text=“ Now there was , of course , no bromide in Dr. Wilkins ’ prescription , but you will remember that I mentioned an empty box of bromide powders .
#Text=One or two of those powders introduced into the full bottle of medicine would effectually precipitate the strychnine , as the book describes , and cause it to be taken in the last dose .

#Text=You will learn later that the person who usually poured out Mrs. Inglethorp ’s medicine was always extremely careful not to shake the bottle , but to leave the sediment at the bottom of it undisturbed .
#Text=“ Throughout the case , there have been evidences that the tragedy was intended to take place on Monday evening .

#Text=On that day , Mrs. Inglethorp ’s bell wire was neatly cut , and on Monday evening Mademoiselle Cynthia was spending the night with friends , so that Mrs. Inglethorp would have been quite alone in the right wing , completely shut off from help of any kind , and would have died , in all probability , before medical aid could have been summoned .

#Text=But in her hurry to be in time for the village entertainment Mrs. Inglethorp forgot to take her medicine , and the next day she lunched away from home , so that the last — and fatal — dose was actually taken twenty-four hours later than had been anticipated by the murderer ; and it is owing to that delay that the final proof — the last link of the chain — is now in my hands . ”
#Text=Amid breathless excitement , he held out three thin strips of paper .
#Text=“ A letter in the murderer ’s own hand-writing , mes amis !
#Text=Had it been a little clearer in its terms , it is possible that Mrs. Inglethorp , warned in time , would have escaped .
#Text=As it was , she realized her danger , but not the manner of it . ”
#Text=In the deathly silence , Poirot pieced together the slips of paper and , clearing his throat , read :
#Text=Dearest Evelyn :
#Text=‘ You will be anxious at hearing nothing .
#Text=It is all right — only it will be to-night instead of last night .
#Text=You understand .
#Text=There ’s a good time coming once the old woman is dead and out of the way .
#Text=No one can possibly bring home the crime to me .
#Text=That idea of yours about the bromides was a stroke of genius !
#Text=But we must be very circumspect .
#Text=A false step — — ’
#Text=“ Here , my friends , the letter breaks off .
#Text=Doubtless the writer was interrupted ; but there can be no question as to his identity .
#Text=We all know this hand-writing and — — ”
#Text=A howl that was almost a scream broke the silence .
#Text=“ You devil !
#Text=How did you get it ? ”
#Text=A chair was overturned .
#Text=Poirot skipped nimbly aside .
#Text=A quick movement on his part , and his assailant fell with a crash .
#Text=“ Messieurs , mesdames , ” said Poirot , with a flourish , “ let me introduce you to the murderer , Mr. Alfred Inglethorp ! ”
#Text=CHAPTER XIII . POIROT EXPLAINS
#Text=“ Poirot , you old villain , ” I said , “ I ’ve half a mind to strangle you !
#Text=What do you mean by deceiving me as you have done ? ”
#Text=We were sitting in the library .
#Text=Several hectic days lay behind us .
#Text=In the room below , John and Mary were together once more , while Alfred Inglethorp and Miss Howard were in custody .
#Text=Now at last , I had Poirot to myself , and could relieve my still burning curiosity .
#Text=Poirot did not answer me for a moment , but at last he said :
#Text=“ I did not deceive you , mon ami .
#Text=At most , I permitted you to deceive yourself . ”
#Text=“ Yes , but why ? ”
#Text=“ Well , it is difficult to explain .
#Text=You see , my friend , you have a nature so honest , and a countenance so transparent , that — enfin , to conceal your feelings is impossible !
#Text=If I had told you my ideas , the very first time you saw Mr. Alfred Inglethorp that astute gentleman would have — in your so expressive idiom — ‘ smelt a rat ’ !
#Text=And then , bonjour to our chances of catching him ! ”
#Text=“ I think that I have more diplomacy than you give me credit for . ”
#Text=“ My friend , ” besought Poirot , “ I implore you , do not enrage yourself !
#Text=Your help has been of the most invaluable .
#Text=It is but the extremely beautiful nature that you have , which made me pause . ”
#Text=“ Well , ” I grumbled , a little mollified .
#Text=“ I still think you might have given me a hint . ”
#Text=“ But I did , my friend .
#Text=Several hints .
#Text=You would not take them .
#Text=Think now , did I ever say to you that I believed John Cavendish guilty ?
#Text=Did I not , on the contrary , tell you that he would almost certainly be acquitted ? ”
#Text=“ Yes , but — — ”
#Text=“ And did I not immediately afterwards speak of the difficulty of bringing the murderer to justice ? Was it not plain to you that I was speaking of two entirely different persons ? ”
#Text=“ No , ” I said , “ it was not plain to me ! ”
#Text=“ Then again , ” continued Poirot , “ at the beginning , did I not repeat to you several times that I did n’t want Mr. Inglethorp arrested now ?
#Text=That should have conveyed something to you . ”
#Text=“ Do you mean to say you suspected him as long ago as that ? ”
#Text=“ Yes .
#Text=To begin with , whoever else might benefit by Mrs. Inglethorp ’s death , her husband would benefit the most .
#Text=There was no getting away from that .

#Text=When I went up to Styles with you that first day , I had no idea as to how the crime had been committed , but from what I knew of Mr. Inglethorp I fancied that it would be very hard to find anything to connect him with it .

#Text=When I arrived at the château , I realized at once that it was Mrs. Inglethorp who had burnt the will ; and there , by the way , you cannot complain , my friend , for I tried my best to force on you the significance of that bedroom fire in midsummer . ”
